message_1:
Which of the following isotopes would undergo beta minus decay to form stable nuclei?

a) Carbon-14
b) Potassium-40
c) Uranium-235
d) Strontium-90
message_2:
Beta minus decay occurs when a neutron in the nucleus is converted into a proton, releasing an electron (beta particle) and an electron antineutrino. This process usually occurs in isotopes with a high neutron-to-proton ratio, as it helps to stabilize the nucleus by increasing the number of protons.

a) Carbon-14 undergoes beta minus decay to form stable Nitrogen-14.
b) Potassium-40 undergoes both beta minus decay to form stable Calcium-40 and beta plus decay to form stable Argon-40.
c) Uranium-235 undergoes alpha decay, not beta minus decay, to eventually form stable Lead-207.
d) Strontium-90 undergoes beta minus decay to form stable Yttrium-90, which then undergoes another beta minus decay to form stable Zirconium-90.

So, the isotopes that undergo beta minus decay to form stable nuclei are Carbon-14, Potassium-40, and Strontium-90.
